reviewText:
Richard Conway is a private detective in the wrong place at the wrong time. Shortly after strapping on his new pair of hypertrousers he finds himself on the receiving end of quite a few pointed fingers, the result of making himself seen on a security camera seconds before a key figure was killed in the same building. Rather than come clean and hope the police believe his story, he decides to take the easy root of breaking into the companies headquarters and destroying the footage, and hopefully getting out with his new coat blood stain free.

Tom Francis's Gunpoint isn't what you might think. This isn't a game about guns, or about pointing them; it's about jumping through windows like a maniacal frog and rewiring security systems to suit your needs. To an outsider I imagine this sounds incredibly silly, but that's part of why it's so brilliant. It manages to be both self aware and hilarious, yet remarkably smart in every aspect of its design, and the pieces come together so perfectly that it never ceased to blow me away as I dug deeper into it.

You could call Gunpoint a platformer, but if anything it's more of a human catapult simulator. Using your futuristic hypertrousers you can jump incredible distances without the worry of a quick death when you hit the ground, or more accurately, smash through a window or onto an unsuspecting guard. Movement is made even more fluid by Conway's spider-like ability to climb walls and cling to ceilings, essentially turning you into the ultimate cat burglar as you effortlessly move through buildings. It's an extremely impressive move set that feels amazing and as if its constantly evolving as you play, with new levels making use of moves you may have never used or even known were possible before, creating a constantly satisfying and stylistic loop of continual mechanical growth.

Standing between you and a parkour bonanza however is a plethora of electronic doors, security switches, cameras, alarms, and other traps that will send you home in a body bag if the guards are alerted, or simply stuck in place. Luckily Conway comes prepared with the ability to hack and rewire these devices to his own uses, with the animatronic like guards being more objects that need to be rerouted than anything resembling human intelligence. This is where Gunpoint evolves into something beyond a clever hook into a ridiculously smart puzzle game, allowing you to quickly reconfigure circuits to set off other devices, open doors, disable guns, and on the whole make you feel like a tech wizard. It's not so much the great mechanics themselves that make Gunpoint an amazing game though, as it is how they are balanced so effortlessly between being clever and keeping the player moving forward, something all to often lost with puzzle games but that Tom Francis has got down to an absolute science. There was never a moment when I felt I wasn't doing something useful in Gunpoint, and even when I failed the brilliant auto save let me quickly restart just seconds prior..

It can't be stressed enough just how much style Gunpoint exudes, from its subtle but unique art design to its masterful noire tinged soundtrack. The graphics are simple yet have a ton of detail squeezed into every pixel, with superb use of lighting setting the mood for a dark detective story and smooth animations allowing you to forget how simple the character designs actually are. Gunpoint succeeds most where so many retro" games fail in making itself instantly identifiable and memorable

This is a great example of a incredibly well done indie game. Absolutely flawless in every aspect I can think of. From graphical representation, gameplay mechanics, level progress to humour and level design, I loved it.

You are in a role of one Richard Conway, a freelance thief, or a cat burglar (I like the way it sounds) who finds himself in a tricky position at the start of the game and has to complete all sorts of missions for his multiple employers to get himself out of the trouble, and learn some secrets along the way. The story itself is very interesting and made me play just one more mission, so I won't spoil any of it, just so you can feel the same way I did.

The main gameplay mechanic we have control over is Crosslink, with which we can rewire the building's electrical skeleton, which consits of various doors, switches, lights, alarms and such that we will manipulate to help us get to the intel we want. Different types of guards make the gameplay more challenging and force you to plan your way more carefully. The missions start out easy and ramp the difficulty up as you progress in the game. After every mission a new contract will be ready for you along with the amount you will recieve upon it's completion.

The characters are very well done, and I really liked the main guy's style and humourous way of dealing with things along the way. You can upgrade your character with new gadgets after every mission, and your own stats, such as longer and quicker jumps.
Fluid gameplay makes playing this game an absolute delight and I have not encountered any bugs in two playthroughs (except for some typos, but it's ok :)) I've gone through.

Oh and there is a level editor, so you can create your own levels and spice it up with everything you got, or you can play other people's creations if you are not a creative type.

Overall:

+ fluid and responsive controls
+ simple, yet aesthetically pleasing graphics
+ great story
+ level design
+ humour
+ level editor

- absolutely nothing

Recommended to everyone, this is a little masterpiece and go do yourself a favour and play it right now.  10/10

reviewText:
Gunpoint
Basic Description:  Gunpoint is a stealth indie puzzler, developed and published by Suspicious Developments. It is sold at full price for £6.00 (but has been sold on Steam previously for £1.20), and has Steam Trading Cards and Achievements.

Gameplay:  The main notable features are the crosslink and wirejack mechanisms, which allow you to rewire electronics and security systems in ways that will allow you to progress and solve the level. The main character – Conway – also possesses ‘Bullfrog Projectile Trousers’ that allow him to jump around the map with enough force to break windows. Throughout the game, you can use upgrade points to improve both the speed and strength of the jump made by these trousers, which are extremely useful during later levels. The levels felt mostly varied, but only 3 guard types made it somewhat easy to slip around undetected. In the shop, the player can purchase additional skills which can aid in their attempts by adding more features and functionality to the Crosslink device. Money and upgrade points are earnt after completing missions. Overall, the difficulty of the game was not hard – the longest time I had spent on a level was around 7 minutes (and this was on the last level), and I’m sure others could complete it quicker – but the acquisition of new upgrades and skills meant that you could revisit older levels and complete them in a faster, more efficient way.

Graphics / Graphical Design:  The graphical design of the game fits extremely well with the setting that the developer was hoping to accomplish, with the design of the main character being a particular success, fitting into the grungy, detective theme that was aimed for. The main overall design is 2D pixel, with all assets made in relatively high quality.

Audio:  The soundtrack of the game was pretty damn good and fitted into the style well; it felt very jazzy at times. Aspects of the soundtrack were of a slightly similar vein to some of the aspects of the Mission: Impossible soundtrack, but this is probably what the developer was hoping to accomplish. The actual sound effects themselves were great, with the only one lacking slightly being the gun, which sounds a bit tinny (and a bit like a cap gun). But overall it was a solid soundtrack that contributed to the overall experience and ambience.

Personal View:  I have to say, this is one of my favourite stealth games and the experience put out by the game was good, solid fun. I never had too much trouble trying to solve levels, with a lot of my time spent figuring out how to get an A+ rating on every level. I particularly enjoyed this game since it allowed me to creatively approach a situation – solutions are not linear, and you can achieve your goal in many different ways. I have finished the game 3 times as you may be able to see from my play time, but each playthrough did not deteriorate in experience.

Replayability:  The average time to complete the story on its own seems to be around 3 hours on average, but more time may be spent gaining the A+ rank on levels based upon the different ‘badges’ you can get - for example, having no witnesses, or making no noise – and this seems reasonable incentive for the player to continue. There is no New Game + mode in this game, but I believe that in this case it does not matter and is not applicable. Some people may not get as much time out of the base game as me, but the amount of workshop levels that have been created is bound to extend the playtime by at least a few hours.

Fun:  I found this game to be a good source of entertainment for at least 10 hours, and in this time I have not completed too many of the (generally well-made) workshop levels. The fun aspect comes from approaching levels in different ways and trying each time to solve the ‘puzzle’ in a different way. It can also be fun to come back after progressing further into the game with more upgrades, as this allows you to potentially unlock new areas of the map.

HIGHLY RECOMMENDED – A solid stealth title with unique mechanics and a decent storyline.

Background
I’ve owned this game for ages. I’d heard such great things about it, but due to an increasingly-large backlog of games that I haven’t touched, this one got shelved and I honestly forgot about it for a long time.
Big mistake. Gunpoint is one of the most unique and enjoyable indie games I’ve played this year. The innovative gameplay style, the storyline, the dialogue, music and aesthetic all came together to create a very nifty little package.

Setting
You play as Richard Conway, a trenchcoat-wearing freelance spy. Immediately after donning your newly-received Bullfrog Hypertrousers (high-tech pants that allows you to make massive leaps), you’ll be summoned by Selena Delgado, an employee for gun manufacturer Rooke. Unfortunately, by the time you ascend the elevators to see her, you find that Selena has been shot. Even worse is the fact that security cameras in the building indicate that you were in the building at the time of the murder, thereby making you the prime suspect.  You're then tasked with clearing your name and finding the true murderer. Throughout the game, you quickly discover that there’s a huge rivalry in the city between two weapons manufacturers, Rooke and Intex, and the murder of Selena Delgado fits somewhere in between this. There are several twists and turns in the story as the mystery surrounding the murder is slowly brought to light.

It’s not the most original or innovative story ever told, but the game breathes extra life into the story to life by giving the main character so much personality. Much of the narrative is told in the form of text messages between you and the people giving you missions to fulfil. During these text-based conversations, you’ll often be given a conversation tree, allowing you to pick your response. Whilst the majority of choices don’t affect the direction of the storyline, many of the lines are incredibly humorous and witty. If you want your version of Richard Conway to be a complete smartass, you’re in luck. It’s been a while since a game has made me laugh out loud like this one.

Gameplay
Despite looking somewhat like a 2D-platformer, Gunpoint is a puzzle game at heart. It plays like a 2D version of Portal in many ways. Rather than using the portal gun, you're instead given two other major abilities that you'll use to complete objectives.

The first of these is your epic super jump, which allows you to jump massive distances and with force great enough to break glass windows. You aim your jump with your left mouse button (which will draw an arc) and release it to make the jump. For whatever reason, you’re also able to climb walls like Spiderman, but we’ll leave that alone for now. The other major ability comes from your Crosslink"

GUNPOINT	Developer: Tom Franchis and others.
Release Date: 3 June 2013
Genre: Platformer, 2D Espionage, Detective, Puzzle
Official Website: http://www.pentadact.com/	What is Gunpoint?	A stealth action platformer game made by an ex PC-GAMER editor Tom Franchis using gamemaker.

The game stars you as Conway, a freelance spy for hire who also happens to be a hat fancier. The game has you break into building quietly or if you happen to be a jerk, loudly, to accomplish your objectives and mission before getting the hell out. Also comes with the unique twist in the form of the wirejack module.	Option Menu	Very Good

You have a wide variety of options to choose from rebindeable keys to colourblind options to the large range of resolution on offer. The only issue is if this incredibly basic game lags on your laptop then the best you can do is lower the resolution since there is no graphical option settings.	Graphic	Good

The game is a stealth 2D espionage game therefor the main concern should be clean graphic style and easy to identify elements all which Gunpoint delivers very well. While the basic sprite based graphics aren't too much of a looker they do have their own charm in Gunpoint noir inspired setting. At the very least you won't confuse the background with the buttons.	Music/Sound Effect[MERGED]	Music:The game has a soothing nostalgic jazz based music while in the menu screen and a quick jumpy music while in mission.

SFX: Very good, other than the fact that gunshot sounds like popcap gun, everything else is near perfect. Especially the SFX of the glass being smashed and guards face being pulverized.	Controls	Excellent

You use the mouse to aim your bullfrog module and alt button to toggle your wirejack. For most part Conway controls well enough to not feel like you're controlling an ice skater in the middle of a competition. 	Gameplay	Now that I have written at length about Gunpoint other point lets touch upon its gameplay mechanic. Your character has a basic device called the Bullfrog Propulsion Module which is the mainstay of most of the mechanic. You press the left mouse button to aim a reticule and releasing the result in which Conway will propel himself rather weakly towards the direction you have given him.

The other highlight is the wirejack system where through a series of module you can buy Conway will turn the electrical grid to his advantage by rewiring doors, calling elevator and other such gameplay elements.

Other than that, it is a fairly standard stealth game.  Guards have cones of vision that you can sneak through using the walls and ceiling or if you are feeling particularly ♥♥♥♥♥♥ you can just Bullfrog straight into them and punch them in the face. That is a legitimate gameplay element. But its not just 1 type of guard no, more will be introduced as you play through the story mode.

Mission usually involves you breaking into a building and either retrieve something or to hack something, basic stuff but the level design and short length of the game keeps it fresh.

After a mission your results will be tallied and you can acquire a skillpoint used to upgrade the Bullfrog charge time and power, the money you earn can also be used to purchase modules for Kenway which ranges from snuffing out the noise he makes when he smashes through glass to him having a gun to literally make a guard stand still at Gunpoint.

Another thing that should be touch upon is that while the game itself is linear the story outcome itself is not, choices of dialogue you made and the result that comes from it will indirectly influence how other character will think of you and will go so far as to change the ending itself.	Conclusion	Recommendation? Yes I will say this a yes old chap. Its a fun quirky little game that does not overstay its welcome while having a rather deep story that encourages a few playthrough to get all of the ending. If you were to trust my words then yes I would tell you to get it and to get it at your convenience.

reviewText:
-Quick Review-
Gunpoint is an indie puzzle game with loose ties to “stealth” and “technology”, Gunpoint was developed by Suspicious Developments and released 2013.


-Detailed breakdown review-
Story: The story is all in written format, somedays I feel like reading all that is writen in a video game, other times I see a chunk of text and think “I don't really care” and skip right into the mission.
Gunpoint lets you skip dialogue and jump right into the puzzle solving action if you feel so inclined, however the story is quite well written. You're a detective and have multiple choices for interaction with your clients. (Naturally I was as condescending and insulting as possible – the reactions were very much worth it!)

Gameplay: The game controls start out very simple, jump, and movement. You jump with the mouse button, and you use ASDW to move right or left, and climb up or down. As you complete various missions you earn skill points that you can spend to improve your skills, and money to unlock upgrades. Some missions require certain upgrades to progress, but generally the game is very doable with minimum upgrades.
Generally there are two elements to the various puzzles you face while playing Gunpoint. Firstly, you need to keep out of the site of guards. This is where the “stealth” tag gets placed on the game. The guards line of site is pretty standard for most games of this genre... Secondly, there is “wiring” you do some very rudimentary “wiring”, for example you can wire a switch to turn off a light, call an elevator, ...and when the elevator arrives it makes a noise and that triggers a sound sensor to open the door in front of you.

Achievements: There are two types of Achievements in this game: Hidden, and visible.
I personally find “hidden” achievements annoying because you can find them by looking at global statistics anyway. (The purpose of hidden achievements are for people to accidentally stumble across them while playing the game.)
After your first play through you will probably have roughly 40% of the achievements, a second play through will earn you another 40% (as long as you do things differently). After my second time through I simply replayed the levels required.
As a side note, you don't need to reset your game and start from scratch like I did, you could just replay old levels. Since the game is such a fast play through anyway, it hardly maters if you reset or not.
One final note, for achievement hunters, this game is an easy 100% completion with relatively less commitment for achievement work.

Price: Gunpoint is priced at $9.99. I personally spent 8.6 hours playing the game. I played through twice, and earned all the achievements. As far as I'm concerned the game value comes out nearly perfectly at 1 dollar an hour. (this is my personal method of measuring a game's play value)
If you're tight on money you could certainly wait for a sale, however... the developers are indie, so supporting them is good!

Conclusion: The game itself was fun, the humor in Gunpoint was hilarious, the story was well written, the gameplay was fun and easy to learn, the achievements were all relatively easy to get but more importantly funny to get (generally the achievement text is a joke based on what's happening in game), the price is as fair as you can expect.
I recommend this game to anyone who enjoys 2D games, indie titles, puzzle games, or “stealth” types of games.
...Maybe all that matters is that I now have the ability to kick down doors. Thanks for reading my review!

This is one the most unique games I've ever laid my hands on.. so to speak.

You play as super cool ultra spy man. With the ability to jump to absurd heights and stick on anything, walls and ceilings included. Each mission has some preamble to give some context and is very clever and quite funny. Your objectives include (mostly hacking into a monitor) or picking up laptops.

The crux of the gameplay is staying out of sight. Turning off lights, hanging off the ceiling and tackling the guards. One simple punch should do the trick. Preceding to the objective and extracting. Buts that not all. You soon discover that you are magic.. or least have the ability to connect things electrically from great distances. This process is called crosslink. You can switch between regular vision and crosslink with a simple flick of your mouse wheel. There are multiple colors which basically identify the different circuits in the building or buildings on the map. You can try things like connecting a switch to a door so that when flicked it operates the door. Did you ever want to be a secret agent? Or a detective who is really good at hiding in the dark? Or just like to beat the living daylights out of someone? Well, Gunpoint lets you do that, and much more. Gunpoint is a 2D indie strategy puzzle game that is visually represented via pixel art (and it’s very well done, might I add) that lets you infiltrate buildings and steal top secret data. Though, unlike most games nowadays, you can’t simply walk in and take the thing. As what the category says, you have to what war veterans would say: strategize; and invent your own solution to the level. This makes the game very interesting, for there are so many options to solve each puzzle. You can turn of lights, and attack the guards in the darkness, or just come up behind them and punch them while their comrades point their guns at you. Also, you don’t take fall damage (because ♥♥♥♥ you, physics) so jumping out of 20 story buildings is okay! Sometimes, Gunpoint can provide some hilarious gameplay.

Gunpoint is exclusive with not only it’s gameplay, but also with it’s storyline. At the start, the story can be quite hard to get a grip of. But when you progress, it becomes a bit easier to understand. On that standpoint; the storyline overall, is brilliant. It’s quite interesting, dark, and sometimes humorous from time to time. Gunpoint also has a very unique little system called “Crosslink”. In this you’re able to change functions of many objects; like to link a button to open a door. This will be your main component in the game, and it’s also very fun to play with. Gunpoint is that kind of game that lets you interact with your environment and change it to your advantage. This can end up to a very interesting way to outsmart the guards, and to trick them. Each level challenges you, slowly getting harder until it’s almost cruel. All of this and more adds up to an original and superb game. To survive, you have to be smart, quick, and clever to maneuver your way around each level, can you do it?

9/10

I recommend this to those who want a mind simulator, a stealth game, and/or a good story, but Gunpoint won’t suit the needs for those are looking for games with good graphics

reviewText:
A superbly executed 2d stealth game with a great story.

Gunpoint takes the fun premise of being a private detective that can jump really high (and survive the accompanying long falls) and turns it into a stealth game with no equal. Each mission has you perform a few simple tasks (usually hack a computer or steal something), the challenge is in getting there. Which can be done in whatever way you wish.

Used to guards seeing you causing a game over? Not in this game.
No way forward except killing the guard always looking at the elevator? Not in this game.
Time limit on the mission so you have to take risks? Not in this game!

Everything is up to your play style, you can be a patient and calculating infiltrator that takes a long time but comes away unseen (and get acknowledged for both of these things) or go in fast and dirty, knocking out all guards in your path (and be acknowledged for both of these things too!).

Between missions you are presented with some well-written conversations between the protagonist and his various employers.
The only thing left I can consider listing are the abilities you can get over the course of the game. You can jump really high, climb all vertical surfaces, hang from ceilings, rewire electronics so a light switch on a different floor opens up a door and, yes, keep guards at Gunpoint.

This game was a delight from start to finish, and my only complaint is that there should be more of it.
There is an extensive level editor, and recently even steamworks support for it, but I want more of the story too!

reviewText:
Digging Yourself Deeper: The Video Game.

Gunpoint is honestly the best game I've played in a long time. It's a little hard for me to describe just how hilariously crazy the narrative gets without spoiling the experience, but when it opens with the protagonist accidentally flinging himself out of a fifth story window you know you're in for a good time.

Yes, the game is short. Very short.  Even without bypassing puzzles by smashing through windows or incapacitating guards, it only took me around three hours to complete the storyline. There are no sidequests and only a handful of collectibles. That's possibly my biggest issue with Gunpoint - the sheer lack of content makes it feels more like a tech demo than a fully fledged game. But considering this is the creator's first game (and made in GameMaker, for Pete's sake) I'm not fussed.

The level editor also might as well be nonexistent. While it's relatively easy to create or install player-made levels yourself, the lack of a Steam workshop means there's barely any public interest in doing so. A dialogue editor also would have been a nice way of making custom stories, but would probably be a nightmare to code. (Edit: Steam Workshop compatability has since been added. Fantastic.)

As much as I'd love a more fleshed-out sequel (or at least some sidestories/sidequests), I'm more interested in seeing what else the creator has in store. Dude's got a lot of promise.

Additional: If you're looking to buy the Special Edition DLC for just the soundtrack, don't bother. Go to the official Bandcamp page instead - it's five dollars cheaper and comes with bonus tracks, remixes and unused audio files.

There's a rare intersection where stealth, puzzles, and story meet, and that's where you'll find Gunpoint. It's hard to nail down as any one particular sort of game, because it does all its constituent parts so incredibly well. Much like a good book, you'll find yourself looking forward to every step of Gunpoint, even as you pine for the part you just came from.

Gunpoint is the story of Richard Conway, a snarky freelance thief who specializes in corporate espionage. A fateful job lands him in the middle of a murder mystery with a surprising number of twists and side stories. Each mission sees you sent into stylish 2D high-rises to pilfer goods or information. There are guards to outwit and doors to unlock, mainly through your clever Crosslink system. Gunpoint lets you wire devices together to make them interact in unexpected ways, like a light switch unlocking a blast door or a trigger pull setting off a wall socket overload.

With the Crosslink at your disposal, levels become sprawling puzzles of networked electronics. You can create incredible chain reactions of chaos and diversions, allowing you to slip past security at just the right moment. A few additional gadgets give you greater flexibility in doing just that, like spring-loaded trousers, climbing gloves, door-flattening kicks, and more. Money earned from missions are used to upgrade your abilities, but levels are designed to be completed with any or none of the optional skills unlocked.

The core gameplay is plenty compelling enough, launching yourself through plate-glass windows and jury-rigging entire skyscrapers to your whims. But it's the writing that elevates Gunpoint to an instant classic. Dialogues between Conway and his clients are snappy, natural, and endlessly entertaining. You get plenty of dialogue choices, split between realistic decisions and creative variations of the same responses. You'll have every opportunity to tell your foes off or ingratiate yourself to the more sympathetic characters, and every branch is its own reward of storytelling.

All of this is wrapped in a delightfully detailed pixel package and a moody noir soundtrack. The menus smack a little of programmer art but that's literally the only complaint I can level against Gunpoint. The story will last you about two hours but they're some of the best gaming has to offer, and there's Workshop support for user-created levels. I'm not saying anything about Gunpoint that hasn't been said a thousand times before, but it's worth my time if I help even one more person discover it. No matter what you enjoy about your games, you're sure to find it here.

reviewText:
There are so many things about this game that I enjoy, and I wish it wasn't over so fast. Replayability comes through branching story threads and community content, but I still want more.

The writing is razor-sharp and full of genuine wit and sarcasm, with the occasional breaking of the fourth wall to comment on gaming conventions. The art is simple but effective, using its minimal tech to create a convincing mood. The jazzy soundtrack is perfect for the story. And while its particular selling point of rewiring the building around you as you sneak through it wasn't implemented as well as it could have been, it still makes for some highly elaborate, complex solutions to puzzles at times.

Everything about it was a treat, and I didn't have any complaints but for its fairly short running time. This is one of my highest recommendations when it comes to indie games.

reviewText:
Gunpoint is a 2D platform puzzle game with simple but solid gameplay. You are a spy who has some projectile trousers that let you jump a very long way and not take damage from falling. Holding the left mouse button lets you aim and power up a jump. You can climb walls and ceilings and smash through glass with your jumps (although doing so will alert nearby enemies).

At its heart it is a puzzle game. How can you get from where you are now, to somewhere else, and then out again? Usually your task is to get to a computer and hack it. You have to get past guards who behave predictably (e.g. a standing guard will always face the same way, unless he hears a noise). As such, you can plan how you'll do it. You can also rewire things like lights and doors, for example, you could make a lightswitch open a door for you. Different parts of a building might be on different circuits, which you can activate by reaching a circuit box of that colour.

You can upgrade your equipment and buy new things as you earn money for the jobs you do. There are usually multiple ways of completing a level, depending on the equipment you have and how much violence you want to use. At the end of a level you are told how many witnesses you left, how violent you were, how noisy you were etc.

The plot follows a murder mystery in which you yourself are implicated. The dialogue is sometimes humourous, but skippable if you just want to play the game. It's not completely linear in that you can choose the order you play many of the levels, but it's quite a short game, and the story is a little confusing such that you might not appreciate what's happening initially. However, there is a level editor and plenty of custom levels in Steam Workshop.

The later levels are bigger and more complex, and I feel like there could have been more levels like that, because overall none of the levels were particularly difficult. But even though the core game is a little short and doesn't have great replayability, it's still a good game and worth a play.

reviewText:
The game presents you with a simple objective (hack this, steal that) each level but gives you a really useful set of tricks to accomplish your goal.  The way this is presented and your control of the game world is what makes this title stand out.  I've managed to wire a light switch to an elevator call button, which sets of a sound alarm which opens a door granting me access to a locked room for example. The game has various electronic devices (buttons, lights, elevators, alarms, doors, cameras) that are nominally assigned to coloured circuits.  You can wire devices up in a building any way you like as long as you don't cross coloured circuits, however judicious use of the aforementioned sound detectors etc. will let you do this.  Play it, makes me think a bit of the cancelled Introversion game 'Subversion'.  I'm not going to mention any of the plot, it's good and serves it's purpose quite well with charm and style.

I really quite like this, the main 'campaign' is short (about 3 or so hours if you fiddle about) but quite wonderfully done.  The levels are very well designed with absolutely loads of routes and tactics that can be taken to beat them.  You really can go back and play each level an entirely different way.  The level designer as it stands I've found easier than most to use, however it seems to be less capabable than the ones used to create the in game levels.  I cannot seem to wire places up to the same degree, and I cannot find any way to access the sound sensors etc. present in the main campaign.  My understanding though is the levels and campaign are straight forward text files so editing/creating anything used in the main campaign is well within reach.

So yes, buy it on the understanding that the included content is quite short but well worth the money and you'll have a minor amount of legwork to do for extra levels (try http://www.gunpointlevels.net/).

An advanced level editor is also available here: http://steamcommunity.com/app/206190/discussions/0/864971139146390709/

Overall, this game is awesome and I think all indie lovers should have it!

In this excellent stealth-puzzler, you play a dude (a some kind of a freelance spy-detective) who just bought hypertrousers. Unfortunately, he got caught on a camera and is now a murder suspect: on to destroy the evidence because who would believe you anyway? Murderer too used the awesometrousers.

This is an excellent game.

Main premise: You are an industrial spy who wears a cool hat and a trenchcoat while trying to solve a murder (and make a killing in the meantime). You have two main abilities to help you do this (besides the hat): the BullFrog Jump Trousers which allow you to jump absurdly high distances and your Crosslink which allows you to hack into nearly any system, influding doors, security cameras, guns, trapdoors, and so on. The game requires you to master both of these abilities to be able to complete the brilliant puzzles it throws at you.

In case you didn't know this already, this is a puzzle game. The main point of the game is to solve puzzles by avoiding (or slaying) guards and hacking systems to acheive some objective.

Another fun element of the game is how much control you have over your character's morality. I personally tried to play the game without killing, hitting, or being seen by any guards, a feat I did not successfully accomplish. You can just as legitimately try to tackle every guard out of a window, however. There isn't that much of a different ending either way, but it was fun to try and solve the puzzles in so many different ways.

All in all, Gunpoint is a great puzzle game that I really enjoyed. My only critique is a relatively small one: the bug causing the game to crash on my computer unless I disable the Steam Overlay is a little irritating, especially because it keeps me from being able to play the Steam Workshop levels. Overall a great game, however. Keep 'em coming!

reviewText: Clever gameplay and storyline, humour and great fun! Gunpoint is the Watch_Dogs before Watch_Dogs in which you play as a hacker who can hack into any eletrical device using his phone to bend it to his will to get revenge on a company for the death of someone he knew (Wow, Ubisoft really ran out of ideas if they are just gonna copy this game.) Definately worth the money, a lot of fun!

The only game I've played similar to this, is the Zero Punctuation Yahtzee's: the Art of Theft. Yes there are other stealth games (Mark of the Ninja comes to mind) or heist sims, but this falls into its own neat little niche.  Again typical start up, you get your briefing - but this can be expanded on, IF you ask the right questions. Your loadout is filled with various upgrades and gadgets, which are slowly acquired so you get used to how each piece works,

The presentation is neat, the controls are pretty good and the murky murder mystery the game opens with is written well enough to compel you to play on.  I enjoyed the deliberate humour, but the mid game shenanigans made me cackle: Like accidentally tackling someone through a 3rd storey window into the tarmac!

Kudos to the Gunpoint crew for their autosave function, rather than relying on a checkpoint system: which wouldn't work for this type of game, they instead record as you play and you can choose a rollback point if things go to hell.

Looking for to more games from these guys.

TL;DR - This game is a fun, albeit short, puzzle game that uses a limited set of mechanics to extract varied, satisfying and solid gameplay; not to mention a bloody hilarious sense of humour.  The campaign will occupy you for ~5hrs, but the level-creator will occupy you for many more.  Definitely recommended.

This is a side-on puzzle game in which you use super-powered trousers and a 'hacking' interface to infiltrate a selection of buildings, extract the information you want, then get the hell out of there; usually through comically jumping through a window and faceplanting the concrete outside.

Both the movement and hacking have been done in an extremely intuitive way, which encourages you to experiment with the environment with your limited toolset to achieve your goal - jumping through glass into a guard and knocking them uncouncious with classic batman-esque sound effects; wiring a switch to a door, slamming it into guards to incapacitate them, hotwiring a plug socket and a siren so that all the guards sprint to the room you want and are promptly electrocuted into unconciousness - it's all extremely satisfying, and the reward of discovering an ability that hasn't been explicitly outlined is tangible.

This summary may make the game sound violent, but any violence in the game is dealt with in a comic, non-gratuitous way; also offering the option to complete every mission non-violently if you so choose (both options are equally viable and as rewarding).

The end of each mission gives you a rating for 'violence', 'witnesses', 'noise', and 'time' - each affecting you overal A-F grade - giving those gamers who enjoy things like speedruns and perfect executions something to aim for; while this really helps the replayability of the campaign alone, the majority of this game's replayability comes from the Steam Workshop - where people have used the game's level-creator to create a huge selection of missions to sink your teeth into.

My only complaint about this game would be the campaign length but, as this is more than made up for by the Workshop, it's nowhere near a dealbreaker and I thoroughly recommend this to anyone looking for an engaging puzzle game that can be picked up and put down as needed.  Top marks.

Gunpoint is a 2d stealth/puzzle game. You can rewire devices in the level to do certain things, such as rewiring a light switch so that instead of turning out the lights, it opens a door into a guard, knocking him out. There are a ton of devices that all do different things when triggered and you can wire almost any combination of triggers/devices together. Your character is also very mobile: you can crawl up walls and hang from the ceiling, and you can superjump with a pair of robolegs your character buys in the opening cutscene. Levels also have a couple of collectibles, in the form of laptops that you can hack to read emails from the game's characters. The characters are really well written, and the dialog is pretty funny. The characters will also give optional goals at the start of levels if you want more of a challenge.

And if you want to spend more than a couple of hours on the game, you had really better go for every one of those challenges and collectibles, because this game is short as HELL. I took my time and meandered about the levels, reset them a few times, and I still beat the whole game in like 3 hours. There's a level editor with workshop integration, but a game shouldn't have to rely on user generated content to last for more than one short sitting.

In short;

PROS: solid gameplay with interesting mechanics, well written characters, funny dialog
CONS: short as hell, can easily be beaten in a few hours

You can rewire devices in the level to do certain things, such as rewiring a light switch so that instead of turning out the lights, it opens a door into a guard, knocking him out. There are a ton of devices that all do different things when triggered and you can wire almost any combination of triggers/devices together. Your character is also very mobile: you can crawl up walls and hang from the ceiling, and you can superjump with a pair of robolegs your character buys in the opening cutscene. Levels also have a couple of collectibles, in the form of laptops that you can hack to read emails from the game's characters. The characters are really well written, and the dialog is pretty funny. The characters will also give optional goals at the start of levels if you want more of a challenge.

And if you want to spend more than a couple of hours on the game, you had really better go for every one of those challenges and collectibles, because this game is short as HELL. I took my time and meandered about the levels, reset them a few times, and I still beat the whole game in like 3 hours. There's a level editor with workshop integration, but a game shouldn't have to rely on user generated content to last for more than one short sitting.

In short;

PROS: solid gameplay with interesting mechanics, well written characters, funny dialog
CONS: short as hell, can easily be beaten in a few hours

This is a stealth game about rewiring things and punching people.  And it's a great game.

Each mission, you're asked to break into a building and reach a computer terminal.  To do this, you need to figure out how to rewire circuits to open the correct doors, while avoiding being shot in the face.  This gives the game a pseudo-puzzle-game feel.  However, if you don't feel like solving puzzles, or are just a generally violent person, you also have the option of pushing the guards out the windows or beating them with your fists.

The best part of this game though is the dialog.  Dear lord that dialog.  Whereas I usually skim over dialog for most games, in this game I found myself genuinely looking forward to the between-mission cutscenes, because the choices you're given are so funny.  I laughed every time.  Every time.

My only complaint is that the game was so short.  It took me 3 hours to beat the first time, and 2 hours to beat a second and get all the achievements.  I don't normally recommend such short games, but I enjoyed the gameplay and humor so much I feel it was worth the cost, even at full-price.

I bought this a while back, when it was on sale, and never really looked at it again. Today I loaded it up, dived in and found a game that realised what made a good puzzle game, ingenuity. You see, you don't have all that much in the way of abilities, apart from being able to jump really high (and fall from great heights safely), being able to punch people out in one hit, and a habit of dying after being hit with anything remotely bulletlike from any angle (although that last one might just be common sense). Soon you get the ability to rewire electronics, which is where the game shines. Each level presents itself as a maze of sorts, where you can open close, break or otherwise wreak havoc with various objects in some remarkably clever ways, all through a simple set of controls.

I know it says stealth up there, but that's really kind of optional. You do kind of have to go the stealthy route (since, again, one bullet = death) you can either be noisy or quiet, or most often a mix of the both. But its rewarding, and doesn't really value one over the other. You can spend a minute setting up a connection so that a door whacks a guard in the face as he walks through it, or you run up behind him and knock him out a window, or come the other way through said window, send glass flying everywhere, land on the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and beat him until the floor is covered in a fine red sludge. Or you could, you know, just go past whilst he's not looking. Your choice

The only real problem I have is that its not very long. I finished it in 3 and a bit hours, and whilst there's a level editor (and presumably the ability to download other people's levels) that might not add too much. Its good, but short.

2 Hours. After finishing Gunpoint, my Steam Library read '2 hours' of gametime. Sounds like a turnoff, right? Well, Gunpoint is crafted in a way that makes 2 hours seem reasonable. After all, Rome wasn't built in a day, but Portal was certainly beaten in an afternoon.

(If you want a short review, I've written a shorter version at the bottom.)

I didn't bring up Portal for only one comparison: I like to think that Gunpoint is like a 2D version of Portal (if that didn't happen to exist already). Yes, there's no psychotic AI lecturing you throughout the story, there's no lasers or energy balls and it's certainly a lot more serious than Portal. However, your main utility lets you get from one place to another quickly, you don't really have a weapon on you, the starring feature of the game is used in a variety of ways, there's some very interesting puzzles that make full use of your surroundings, the game can be beaten in a single day and the humour will make you smile multiple times (personally, I think it beats Portal).

So, enough of the similarites to the puzzle game with myths concerning baked goods, what makes Gunpoint unique? Hypertrousers and the Crosslink. The former lets you leap great heights and survive them (your enemies can't); the latter  lets you rewire electronic devices to others, such as light switches to electric sockets or security cameras to doors. These two features make up the main gameplay and are VERY satisfying. Timing a pounce onto a guard and knocking him out of a glass window never got boring for me and screwing around with the Crosslink led to entertaining solutions to problems (like knocking out a guard by opening a door quickly in his face). Combine this with upgrades like larger jumps and new gadgets such as silently breaking glass or rewiring GUNS and it all works together very nicely. Every puzzle gives you a way to try again, you'll never find yourself trapped in a room from screwing up: every puzzle in Gunpoint has a solution.

The plot typically follows a noir detective setting, in modern times. You play as a freelance spy, taking on jobs in search of pay who gets caught up in a murder mystery involving rival companies, friends and people all with different motives. Each character feels different from each other in personality, which is quite the acheivement for a game where the characters are only pixelated faces and text. As these characters give you instructions, there are points where you're given 2 sides to a point, and you have to choose which one to side with. The last one is a real morality question; it WILL make you think. Conversations take place on your phone, and you have multiple responses you can make to what you're told. These can range from serious, shady quotes, to questions about your mission, to humour that physically made me laugh out loud, something Portal couldn't achieve. Speaking of humour, it's all very well-written but keeps the serious tone throughout, something I can applaud. Some of the achivements account for this humour too, such as getting one for the previous action of knocking a guard out with a door, hitting yourself with a door, and my personal favourite: punching a guard in the face over 50 times until you get an achievement begging you to stop.

As for presentation, I love it all. It takes on a retro style of pixelated characters and backgrounds but still keeps them very detailed, from graffiti on the street walls in the distance to the apartment windows in the background being on or off. THAT is good detail. Fitting the noir style, the music is mainly jazz with techno mixed in at some areas to fit your hacking abilities. It's very smooth and relaxing but also fits the mood of the mission you're on. It's simple, but effective. And great to listen to as you punch a guard in the face over 50 times until you get an achievement beggin you to stop.

CONCLUSION/SHORT REVIEW

I love Gunpoint. I love its originality, I love the humour, I love the music and the campaign length personally doesn't bother me. While it's easy to catch on, it's not so easy that mental effort isn't required - I'd say medium on the challenging scale. If just doing the bare minimum, one can finish this game in a matter of hours, but there are extra achievements possible for doing levels with a specific style or speed if that's your kind of thing.

The dialogue is cute and made me laugh. While it's not an adventure game per say, you are given a few choices that will affect the game. And the ability to choose different dialogue options in between missions made me feel more invested in my character. (For example, I made my character as snarky as possible.) The beauty of Gunpoint is its simplicity: the visuals are low-fi, but the gameplay is decidedly high-tech. Equipped with mechanical trousers that permit you to leap tall buildings in a--well, a couple of bounds--you assume the role of a detective caught up in a murder conspiracy, armed with only your pants and a couple of upgrades.

It's one of the most deliciously well-written, atmospheric, and satisfying puzzlers I've played in a long time.

VISUALS: Simple and clean, pixel-art that communicates the environment without any clutter to distract you from the gameplay.

SOUND/MUSIC: The tunes in this game are legitimately good listening all on their own, but they add a noir ambience that is undeniably a character unto itself.

GAMEPLAY: Aside from acrobatic feats, you can use a wiremapping device to re-wire entire buildings, so that a light-switch in one room might short a light socket in another--and thereby electrocute and pacify a patrolling guard. There are many opportunities for game-breaking shenanigans here. Add in a level creator and you've got room for plenty of replayability.

2 Hours. After finishing Gunpoint, my Steam Library read '2 hours' of gametime. Sounds like a turnoff, right? Well, Gunpoint is crafted in a way that makes 2 hours seem reasonable. After all, Rome wasn't built in a day, but Portal was certainly beaten in an afternoon.

(If you want a short review, I've written a shorter version at the bottom.)

I didn't bring up Portal for only one comparison: I like to think that Gunpoint is like a 2D version of Portal (if that didn't happen to exist already). Yes, there's no psychotic AI lecturing you throughout the story, there's no lasers or energy balls and it's certainly a lot more serious than Portal. However, your main utility lets you get from one place to another quickly, you don't really have a weapon on you, the starring feature of the game is used in a variety of ways, there's some very interesting puzzles that make full use of your surroundings, the game can be beaten in a single day and the humour will make you smile multiple times (personally, I think it beats Portal).

So, enough of the similarites to the puzzle game with myths concerning baked goods, what makes Gunpoint unique? Hypertrousers and the Crosslink. The former lets you leap great heights and survive them (your enemies can't); the latter  lets you rewire electronic devices to others, such as light switches to electric sockets or security cameras to doors. These two features make up the main gameplay and are VERY satisfying. Timing a pounce onto a guard and knocking him out of a glass window never got boring for me and screwing around with the Crosslink led to entertaining solutions to problems (like knocking out a guard by opening a door quickly in his face). Combine this with upgrades like larger jumps and new gadgets such as silently breaking glass or rewiring GUNS and it all works together very nicely. Every puzzle gives you a way to try again, you'll never find yourself trapped in a room from screwing up: every puzzle in Gunpoint has a solution.

The plot typically follows a noir detective setting, in modern times. You play as a freelance spy, taking on jobs in search of pay who gets caught up in a murder mystery involving rival companies, friends and people all with different motives. Each character feels different from each other in personality, which is quite the acheivement for a game where the characters are only pixelated faces and text. As these characters give you instructions, there are points where you're given 2 sides to a point, and you have to choose which one to side with. The last one is a real morality question; it WILL make you think. Conversations take place on your phone, and you have multiple responses you can make to what you're told. These can range from serious, shady quotes, to questions about your mission, to humour that physically made me laugh out loud, something Portal couldn't achieve. Speaking of humour, it's all very well-written but keeps the serious tone throughout, something I can applaud. Some of the achivements account for this humour too, such as getting one for the previous action of knocking a guard out with a door, hitting yourself with a door, and my personal favourite: punching a guard in the face over 50 times until you get an achievement begging you to stop.

As for presentation, I love it all. It takes on a retro style of pixelated characters and backgrounds but still keeps them very detailed, from graffiti on the street walls in the distance to the apartment windows in the background being on or off. THAT is good detail. Fitting the noir style, the music is mainly jazz with techno mixed in at some areas to fit your hacking abilities. It's very smooth and relaxing but also fits the mood of the mission you're on. It's simple, but effective. And great to listen to as you punch a guard in the face over 50 times until you get an achievement beggin you to stop.

CONCLUSION/SHORT REVIEW

I love Gunpoint. I love its originality, I love the humour, I love the music and the campaign length personally doesn't bother me. It's short enough to avoid being stale but long enough to make you satisifed. If you like noir settings and fun, clever puzzle games, pick this up. If you want something new, pick this up. I bought this on sale and personally wouldn't have minded paying the full price, though that's just me. If it's too short for you, there's multiple story decisions to make which affect your outcome, as well as Steam workshop maps to try out.

(If  you want to see how I did, click the link to see the games' final surprise. Don't worry, there's no spoilers for the plot. http://www.pentadact.com/category/conwaysblog/?K=14&U=30&C0=1&E1=1&C1=2&E2=1&C2=1&C3=3&C4=3&C5=1)

As a final statement, let me just say this. Thank you Fabian Van Dommelen and John Roberts, your attention to detail and skill is brilliant. Thank you Ryan Ike, John Robert Matz and Francisco Cerda, 'Security, Circuitry and You' is going to be travelling through my ears for the next few months. And thank you, Tom Francis. You made a hell of a game.

Gunpoint is a stealth puzzle game just as the developer says, and is a very competent game as well. The game boils down to its two main mechanics and ties in a detective story with some humor too. With some simple gameplay mechanics, the level design is done in such a way to take full advantage of your toolset for some invigorating puzzles and stealth.

The story in Gunpoint revolves around freelance spy Richard Conway, as he tries to clear his name from someone’s murder and solve a murder mystery. The majority of the story is told through messages on Conway’s phone, and this is where the humor comes in. You the player are given multiple dialog options, and several of Conway’s responses are snarky or bizarre in context. Whichever response is picked, there’s bound to be some good laughs at the overall script and the player dialog. In the main game there are a few choices to be made. They do change the story slightly, though the levels remain mostly the same. Anyhow, the strong film noir story works out fine with some excellent humor mixed in, along with good variety in dialog responses and story choices to mix things up.

Gunpoint’s stealth puzzle gameplay is in two distinct pieces. The first is the Bullfrog, a set of trousers that allow Conway to leap really tall distances and at a high speed. Conway can also pounce on enemies and punch them either to knock them out or to death. The second is the Crosslink, a tool to hack and rewire electrical components together to solve puzzles. These two components are the basis for the puzzles and stealth of the game, with the levels strongly using these mechanics in interesting ways. Throughout the game, unlocks can be received, either through using skill points for upgrading the Bullfrog and battery system or for unlocking new abilities. The new abilities tie in closely with the core mechanics, and serve to augment certain playstyles players may have as they complete each level. The levels and abilities serve multiple kinds of solutions, whether it be violent engagements or undetected stealth. With these two gameplay mechanics and great level design that gives players multiple ways to solve them, Gunpoint’s stealth puzzle gameplay is quite open ended on giving players freedom using just these two main tools.

The art style of Gunpoint is a 2d pixelated style. The world of Gunpoint is pretty well detailed, while still having a pixel art style that isn’t too retro. The environments do a great job in expressing the film noir style with the different buildings and the urban setting, with relatively simple character and object models to make gameplay streamlined with easy to see designs. Overall it’s a mix of good detail in the buildings and backgrounds, with more simple designs on characters and objects to easily stick out in gameplay.

The music of Gunpoint is an excellent jazzy soundtrack. Since this game is heavily inspired by film noir, it would only be natural to have the music reflect that style. Each of the music pieces range from slower songs played in the menu or during the phone dialog, to faster songs well suited to the espionage during gameplay. The songs played during gameplay have essentially two versions, one when the view is normal and the other when Crosslink mode is active. It’s a very nice touch that helps to identify which mode the player is in, and suits the current display too with a more electronic style when hacking along with the jazzy style while in the main view. The music of Gunpoint brings in some nice sounding jazz that sounds great while playing through both the story and gameplay sections.

Gunpoint takes stealth puzzle gameplay with its two main mechanics: leaping and hacking. The game takes these concepts and uses them in new ways with its levels and unlockable abilities. Alongside that is a film noir story that packs some solid humor with both the overall script and possible dialog choices. To tie the game together are a fitting detailed pixel art style and a solid jazz soundtrack that makes gameplay fun and fitting to the theme. Gunpoint plays well with these elements for a unique game experience that is fun to play through along with some bright ideas for some smart game design.

It is difficult not to compare 'Gunpoint' and 'Watch_Dogs'. I played 'Watch_Dogs' before 'Gunpoint', with the latter released about a year and half earlier. I liked 'Watch_Dogs'; it's good (but not $69.99 good, making me feel lucky that I got my free copy from nVidia), but I feel that it is not as polished as it could have been and some features could have been implemented better.

This brings us to 'Gunpoint', which ironically features less guns than 'Watch_Dogs'. Both games require players to use hacking as a tool to solve puzzles, but 'Gunpoint' implements the hacking better and is a more polished game. Its game design actually puts hacking into the forefront and encourages players to complete the game in a stealthy, non-lethal and even non-violent ways. You need to think creatively to solve the puzzles, especially if you aim for an A or A+ rating. Completing a mission with a high rating is, therefore, very rewarding. The game's replayability is very high as it also includes a level editor.

On the other hand, the hacking in 'Watch_Dogs', while fun at times, seems like an afterthought and gimmicky. In some 'Watch_Dogs' missions, it is often easier to shoot than to hack your way out of a difficult situation. I think most people will agree with me that the best parts of 'Watch_Dogs' are ones where your hacking skills and wit are your only disposable tools. 'Gunpoint' is pretty much all these best parts"

reviewText:
Gunpoint is a good game with a good story. On paper, it might seem difficult, but it's actually pretty easy once you understand the hacking mechanics. It's on the short side, so you can breeze right through it in a few hours.

The story revolves around a freelance espionage agent that is startled by a murder in a building next to his apartment building. He only ends up investigating it because he sets off these new spring shoes he bought which launches him into the murder building. Conway ends up being part of a conspiracy and helps track down the real killer why also figuring out why the victim was killed.

Good game. Good soundtrack.

8.5/10

Gunpoint is like a mix of Hotline Miami, Mark of the Ninja, and Arkham Asylum. You're a corporate spy in a 2-D world trying to solve a murder that you unwittingly pin on yourself. Each mission involves avoiding or knocking out guards, re-wiring electrical systems, smashing through windows, and hanging off the walls like Batman. You can jump ultra-high too without hurting yourself. Late in the game you can pull out your gun, but I don't recommend it.

You gain abilities by purchasing them in the store, and take missions for a variety of (competing) clients. You communicate with them via text message, and the conversations are often hilarious. They may have a variety of requests - complete the mission without hurting anyone, or kill everyone, or be completely silent.

Manipulating the various buildings is simple but extremely fun, and doesn't get old for the three hours it takes to beat the game. Given the length it might be a stretch to recommend this one at full price, but at $5 or less it's a no-brainer.

Some performance notes: it's more demanding than a 2-d pixel art game warrants. My 2010 Macbook couldn't play it, despite meeting the minimum Mac requirements. I have 4.6 hours of playtime because the first 1.6 hours were spent struggling to try to play it on the Macbook before I gave up and played it on my main rig.
It's a beautiful game. Solid Gameplay Mechanics, Funny/Badass Story, And The Best Secret Achievement You Could Ever Get.
